JOHN SHIMKUS, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF ILLINOIS</opening> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The Subcommittee on the Environment will now come to order. The chair recognizes himself for 5 minutes for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Today's hearing examines the impact of the EPA's new source review air permitting program, commonly referred to as NSR.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Congress created this preconstruction permitting program with the goal of protecting air quality by ensuring that the use of appropriate pollution control devices on new and modified source of emissions such as power plants, factories, and industrial facilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">As you can imagine, the NSR permitting program reaches across several industry sectors and has far-reaching impacts on America's economy and global competitiveness. For these reasons, it is incredibly important for us to ensure that the preconstruction permitting program is working effectively and efficiently.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Unfortunately, history shows that there are too many instances where New Source Review Program is anything but effective and efficient.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">As we will hear from many of our witnesses today, over time the NSR program has become more costly and time consuming which not only slows economic growth but also hinders the nation's ability to modernize infrastructure.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Under the existing NSR program, it can take multiple years and millions of dollars to obtain the preconstruction air permits required to begin construction on a new facility. This significant time delay and cost burden makes it more difficult and less likely for owners to invest in new projects and facilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Not only is the NSR process costly and time consuming, it is also complex and uncertain. Right now, on the EPA's Web site there are nearly 700 posted guidance documents that an applicant may need to be aware of when seeking a preconstruction permit.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Companies must hire teams of lawyers just understand the requirements and processes established under the NSR program. The end result of this complexity is that companies are afraid of incorrectly interpreting NSR requirements and violating the rules that they are hesitant to pursue projects that require an NSR preconstruction permit.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">In other words, the NSR program is holding back needed investment in the nation's infrastructure, industrial capacity, and manufacturing capabilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">One particularly frustrating effect of the NSR program is that it discourages owners from carrying out projects that would improve the environmental performance of their facilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">For example, if a company wants to perform efficiency upgrades to install new pollution control technology, they typically have to obtain a preconstruction permit through the NSR program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">However, because the NSR program is so burdensome, many owners are choosing to avoid the NSR process and facility upgrades altogether and are instead continuing to operate older, less efficient, and dirtier facilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Clearly, there are significant problems and shortcomings with how the NSR program is being carried out today. The goal of this hearing is to identify and understand the challenges connected to the NSR program so that we can begin considering potential reforms to improve the program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">To assist our work, we will hear today from witnesses who can explain the challenges faced by manufacturers and industry seeking to expand operations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We will hear from a state regulator who can explain the role NSR program plays in protecting local air quality and we will also hear from NSR policy experts who can discuss options for how to reduce unnecessary NSR permitting burdens.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. PAUL TONKO, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. PAUL TONKO"> And with that, I'd like to yield--so I will turn to the minority--are you ready to go? I would like to recognize the ranking member of the subcommittee, Mr. Tonko, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you, Mr. Chair, and thank you to our witnesses for being here today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Today's hearing will examine EPA's new source review permitting program. As we have discussed on many occasions in this subcommittee, under the Clean Air Act, EPA is required to set health-based national ambient air quality standards, or NAAQS, for six criteria pollutants.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Tonko">As more medical and scientific evidence has come to light, NAAQS have been adjusted accordingly to ensure they continue to be protective of our health.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Since the passage of the Clean Air Act, our nation has experienced the drastic reduction in these air pollutants, all while our economy has grown tremendously.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Tonko">It is beyond dispute that air pollution has serious health and economic consequences. When people are sick, hospitalized, and miss school are work we are a less productive society.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The new source review program plays an important role to ensure that new and modified major sources use the appropriate pollution controls to limit emissions of criteria pollutants.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Tonko">This includes the best available controlled technology and locations with relatively clean air known as prevention of significant deterioration to ensure these areas continue to maintain healthy levels of air quality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Tonko">For areas in nonattainment of a NAAQS this includes the lowest achievement emissions rate along with appropriate offsets from other existing sources. This is known as nonattainment new source review.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The Clean Air Act has been successful because it is premised on making progress over time. We have made major strides in reducing pollution as our understanding of the health risks posed by dirty air has become more sophisticated.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Tonko">That is why I was pleased to see EPA's Web site recognized February as American Heart Month. EPA has some useful heart health statistics such as heart disease and stroke are the first and fourth leading causes of death in the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Air pollution can affect heart health and can trigger heart attacks and strokes that cause disability and death. One in three American adults has heart or blood vessel disease and is at higher risk from air pollution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Tonko">It is critical that we acknowledge and educate people on the role air pollution plays in exacerbating heart disease, asthma, and other respiratory illnesses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So while EPA's Web site has taken steps to connect the dots between air pollution and threats to Americans' health, the actions by Administrator Pruitt and Assistant Administrator Wehrum have been troubling.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Tonko">On December 7th, Administrator Pruitt issued a memorandum with a new approach to implementation and enforcement of the new source review program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Tonko">EPA will no longer review the permanent applicant's emissions projections nor will the agency enforce against an applicant that provides invalid estimates.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Tonko">In some cases, this lax attitude on enforcement will have consequences in downwind states, far away from the original permitting authority.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And while not the subject of today's hearing, another data point from January 25th, Assistant Administrator Wehrum reversed EPA's longstanding once in always in policy for major source MACT requirements.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Both decisions will review--will result, rather, in greater air pollution, and the new source review task force seems to be little more than a brainstorming session on how to evade air pollution controls rather than actually building a public record on how the program might be improved.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Progress over time means ensuring we don't backslide and, sadly, I believe the direction of this EPA will cause us to do just that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Tonko">My district and many great towns and cities across this country were built by manufacturers. But when many of those facilities were built, we didn't fully understand the consequences of dirty air. We didn't know that one in three American adults has heart or blood vessel disease and is at higher risk from air pollution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Tonko">We know better today. Our health and environmental safeguards should reflect that. We shouldn't have to ask our constituents to bear all the costs of air pollution, especially not when they are--when there are effective and well understood pollution controls.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I would urge EPA's leadership to stop going down this path and consider how the--how to best improve and preserve air quality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So again, I thank you. I thank the witnesses for being here and helping us better understand some of the potential changes to the new source review program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> And with that, Mr. Chair, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Gentleman yields back his time.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. GREG WALDEN, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF OREGON</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. GREG WALDEN"> The chair now recognizes the chairman of the full committee, Mr. Walden for Oregon, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Walden">I thank the gentleman and appreciate the witnesses being here today. We look forward to your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Walden">As we all know, the purpose of the Clean Air Act is, and I quote, to protect and enhance the quality of the nation's air resources, to promote the public health and welfare and the productive capacity of its population, closed quote.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Walden">So in today's hearing, we will highlight the necessity to ensure the rules to protect and improve air quality, promote both of these core objectives.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Walden">Effective clean air regulations should allow the nation to continue to expand its manufacturing and industrial capacity. But these goals are undermined when regulatory requirements no longer reflect practical reality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Walden">As a result, American communities are deprived of both continued environmental improvements and economic prosperity. The new source review permitting process serves as a case in point.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Walden">Permitting requirements under EPA's NSR program have evolved in complexity and confusions as the program began in the 1970s and as a result complex preconstruction planning requirements present unnecessary delays and impediments to the expansion of manufacturing and industrial facilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Walden">As we will hear in the testimony today, the complexity of the NSR process permitting time delays and regulatory uncertainty create powerful incentives to forego needed project upgrades even in areas that meet current air quality standards.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Walden">And for other communities NSR complexity raises costs and otherwise harms the prospects for economic expansion and increased environmental benefits.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Walden">In fact, the burdens associated with NSR can lead to communities losing the emissions benefits offered by more efficient modern technologies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Walden">Prineville, Oregon--that's in my district. Home to data centers for Facebook and Apple. Recently, a proposed data center expansion ran headlong into a permitting issue because of potential backup generator emissions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Walden">A single air sampling location, just one, and restrictive air quality rules made it unclear whether or not the expansion could go forward. It was only after the city persuaded the EPA to add an additional sampling location that they were then able to resolve the issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Walden">That instance involved hundreds of millions of dollars in investments and hundreds of construction jobs. Multiply that by the thousands of projects waiting to take off around the nation--around the nation in response to our reformed tax structure and the urgency of addressing NSR problems becomes apparent.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Walden">I would also say that when you're dealing with companies the capital and intellectual capacity of Facebook and Apple they are probably better positioned to challenge some of these issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Walden">The witnesses today, you all bring a range of perspectives on the NSR permitting process. We appreciate your willingness to help us understand the challenges of the current process and what we can do to improve upon it.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Greg Walden</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon.
